misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes array positions start at 1 (the “first position” is index 1 and the “last position” is index arraySize), so loops should run from 1 to arraySize inclusive.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed: valid indices are 0 to arraySize-1. Index arraySize is out of bounds. This affects reading input, accessing the last element, shifting, and printing. Using 1-based indexing causes ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException and also skips index 0 entirely.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) and incorrect shifting/printing even if it didn’t crash.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Off-by-one boundary model for “cover all elements”
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that to ‘cover all elements’ you should use <= arraySize (inclusive end), and that starting at 1 still covers everything important.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java loops over an array almost always use < array.length, not <=, because the last valid index is length-1. Inclusive bounds accidentally step one past the end. Also, starting at 1 means the element at index 0 is never read/printed/shifted, so the array is not fully processed.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception and/or missing element(s) in output (index 0 never handled).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Misidentifying the “last element” location in memory
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the last element is stored at position arraySize, matching the human idea of “the Nth element,” rather than at index arraySize-1.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, the Nth element (in human counting) corresponds to index N-1. So the ‘last element’ is at index arraySize-1. Accessing index arraySize is always invalid for a size-N array.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception when trying to read the last element (or later when shifting).

evidence.code_snippet:
// The last element should be at position arraySize
int lastElementValue = userInputArray[arraySize];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that arrays in Java are indexed starting from 1, similar to how we count in natural language ('the first element', 'the second element'). When we talk about 'position 1', the student maps this mentally to the conceptual first element.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays use 0-based indexing. The first element is at index 0, not index 1. When the student writes 'userInputArray[1]' they are actually accessing the second position in the array. This causes the code to skip index 0 entirely and attempt to access index arraySize (which is out of bounds). The array's actual structure is [unused, element1, element2, element3, ...] rather than [element1, element2, element3, ...].
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when trying to read input or access the last element, because userInputArray[arraySize] is out of bounds. Additionally, even if it didn't crash, the actual first position (index 0) would remain uninitialized and print as 0.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Natural Language Mapping to Code Structure
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when we say 'the first position' or 'position 1', this directly corresponds to array index 1, because in everyday English we count starting from 1. The student is trying to make the code match natural language descriptions.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java's array indexing is purely positional and mathematical, not linguistic. While humans naturally say 'first, second, third', Java uses 0-based indexing for technical reasons (offset-based memory access). The student conflates the ordinal number (first = 1st) with the array index (first = 0). These are different concepts in programming.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Off-by-one errors throughout: incorrect array access, potential bounds violations, and logical errors in the shift operation.

evidence.code_snippet:
// The last element should be at position arraySize
int lastElementValue = userInputArray[arraySize];

// The first position feels like 1
userInputArray[1] = lastElementValue;

// I want to cover all elements, so I count from 1 up to arraySize
for (int arrayIndex = 1; arrayIndex <= arraySize; arrayIndex++)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array elements are indexed starting from 1 up to the length of the array, mirroring how one naturally counts items (1st, 2nd, 3rd, etc.).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays use zero-based indexing. This means the first element is at index 0 and the last element is at index (length - 1). Attempting to access index 'length' triggers a runtime exception because that memory location is outside the array's bounds.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that an array allocated with size 'N' contains a slot at index 'N'.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to realize that the 'size' provided during array instantiation defines the total count of elements, not the maximum indexable value. Because indexing starts at 0, the maximum index is always one less than the size.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: 1-based array indexing (treating Java arrays like they start at 1)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes array positions naturally start at 1 (first element is at index 1), and therefore the last element is at index arraySize. They also believe looping from 1 through arraySize (inclusive) will cover every element exactly once.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are **0-based**: the first element is at index 0 and the last element is at index arraySize - 1. Valid indices are 0..arraySize-1. Any access to userInputArray[arraySize] or userInputArray[1] as the “first element” (when arraySize could be 1) can go out of bounds. Loops must respect these index rules; using <= arraySize with a 0-based array typically causes an out-of-range access on the final iteration.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime error (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) during input, shifting, or printing; and even if it didn’t crash, the shift logic would not operate on the intended elements because the indexing model is off by one.

evidence.code_snippet: // I want to cover all elements, so I count from 1 up to arraySize
// The last element should be at position arraySize
// I want to print all elements, so I go from 1 to arraySize

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays use 1-based indexing, similar to mathematical notation or arrays in some other languages. They think the first element is at index 1, the second at index 2, and so on. They also believe that an array of size N has valid indices from 1 to N (inclusive).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays are 0-indexed: valid indices range from 0 to N-1 for an array of size N. The first element is always at index 0, not index 1. This is a fundamental difference from mathematical notation where sequences are often written as a₁, a₂, ..., aₙ. When the student accesses userInputArray[arraySize], they are attempting to read past the end of the array, causing an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at line 29 when attempting to access userInputArray[arraySize]. Additionally, index 0 of the array is never populated by user input, remaining at the default value of 0, and the logic for shifting and placement becomes incorrect.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that arrays follow human counting conventions where the first element is located at index 1 and the final element is located at the index equal to the array's size.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays use zero-based indexing. The first element is always at index 0, and the last valid index is always length - 1. Accessing an index equal to the array's size (N) results in a runtime error because the memory is only allocated for indices 0 through N-1.
